awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: In vivo Deep Tissue Imaging with Ultrafast, Volumetric Super-Resolution Microscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Jia, Shu / Ying, Leslie 
1604565 / 1604531 

This work will advance the discovery and understanding of the brain, improve healthcare, and enhance infrastructure for research and education. The project will lay the foundation for a better understanding of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's in both biological and clinical investigations. The super-resolution spectroscopy advances will provide fast, molecular level, non-invasive, high specificity imaging tools for translational medical applications.

This project will develop a new volumetric, ultrafast super-resolution microscopy to overcome technical barriers for in vivo investigations of tissue and organ functions. Switching methods, such as stochastic optical reconstruction microscopy (STORM) rely on imaging of single molecules to reconstruct fluorescence images with sub-diffraction-limited resolution. The roles of microglia in response to Ab (Amyloid beta) are crucially involved in the diseased (AD) brain; and ultimately provide tools and solutions for clinical investigations. The proposed super-resolution investigation will provide new insights into the role of microglia to the maintenance of brain function and in response to pathological insults. The proposed work will pave the technological and intellectual foundation for deeper understanding of the microglial response and influence to neurodegenerative disorders.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report (1604565, 07/2016-06/2020)

Collaborative Research: in vivo deep tissue imaging with ultrafast, volumetric super-resolution microscopy.

In collaboration with Dr. Leslie Ying at SUNY Buffalo, this project aims todevelop volumetric, ultrafast super-resolution STORM microscopy for in vivo investigations of tissueand organ functions. The research goals have been achieved through a series of innovationsin imaging physics, engineering, and computation, including novel single-molecule localizationmethods based on PSF-engineering and adaptive optics, as well as machine learning-enabled STORM microscopy. In the grant period (2016-2020), our research efforts have been directed to realize a set of new concepts and technologies in super-resolution,light-field, computational, optofluidic, and miniature microscopy. These results have led to 8 peer-reviewed journal papers and 2 pending US patents. The major outcomes and impacts include:

I. Wave Physics and Super-Resolution Microscopy. The development aims to probe intracellularcomplexities and heterogeneity in cells and tissues with 3D ultrahigh-resolution, volumetric capability, high throughput and sensitivity, and platform generalizability. The PI has achieved innovations focused on fundamental imaging physics and super-resolution imaging methodology. 

II. Light-Field Microscopy and Computational Microscopy. The development aims to enable ultrafast, in vivo imaging and the interrogation of multi-scale, volumetric biological dynamics and activities. The PI has achieved innovations focused on light-field imaging technology and computational tools. 

III. Miniature Microscopy and Camera Physics. The development aims to transform conventional imaging platforms and enhance imaging device accessibility to wide-ranging imaging conditions, modalities,and biological systems. The PI has achieved innovations focused on miniature and integrated imaging systems and camera physics.

In Broader Impacts, Dr. Jia has recruited 5 undergraduates (3 female) in the project and delivered>10 national and international tutorials and seminars. The PI was selected as a Class of 1969Teaching Fellow in 2019 to learn and  practice innovative, evidence-based teaching methods withthe Center for Teaching and Learning (CTL) at Georgia Tech. The PI was also selected as a Woodruff AcademicLeadership Fellow in 2021. Dr. Jia has conducted educationaloutreach as the STEM science advisor to the Central Islip School in NY and Atlanta Public Schools. Dr. Jia and colleagues have established the Initiative for Leadership in STEM to train Long Island high-school STEM teachers to develop in-depth knowledge, practices, and curricula. In the Atlanta metropolitan, the PI has been collaborating with the Georgia Academy of Sciences to train STEM students in Atlanta Public Schools (APS). The PI has also collaborated with the Summer UndergraduateResearch in Engineering/Sciences (SURE) program at Georgia Tech to engage students inresearch from traditionally underrepresented colleges nationwide.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Shu Jia
